did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN HOLMES.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Paul Mellon Bequest. #11619. Printed: L and B XV, 248-50.

scopecontent.p: T. J. thanks Holmes for a copy of his pamphlet Mr. Holmes' letter to the people of Maine in which Holmes argued that any restriction on the admission of Missouri would be unconstitutional. T. J. responds that the issue of the extension of slavery to the territories which was temporarily solved by the Missouri Compromise has "like a fire-bell in the night, awakened and filled me with terror. I considered it at once as the knell of the Union." He writes of the difficulty of a practical solution to the issue of slavery and emancipation for "we have the wolf by the ear, and we can neither hold him, nor safely let him go. Justice is in one scale, and self-preservation in the other." T. J. believes that a diffusion of slavery over a broader territory would make emancipation easier and cautions against Congress interfering in state issues. He concludes that he will now die believing "that the useless sacrifice of themselves by the generation of 1776 ... is to be thrown away by the unwise and unworthy passions of their sons, and that my only consolation is to be, that I live not to weep over it." [2974-a]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN WAYLES EPPES, Mill Brook, Va.
did.physdesc: ALS. 6 pp. #38-576. Another MS. in MHi.

scopecontent.p: Delay in opening of seminary because of its conversion into a public university. Terms of loan to University tie up all funds for next five years; hopes for remitting of loan. Francis Eppes' education with Mr. Stack and Mr. Ragland. Recommends he go to Columbia College to study under Cooper rather than to Eastern colleges. Plans for selling slaves to Eppes to pay his debts. Hopes for compromise in his commitment for Wilson Cary Nicholas' debt. Insists that women slaves be included in sale, which will produce addition capital in the future. Part of Poplar Forest to be given to Francis Eppes. Accepts his offer of the harpsichord for Poplar Forest. Invites Eppes to visit Monticello to see the University. Describes present and projected buildings. [1798]

Mentions Pierre Jean George Cabanis, Mr. Nulty, Joseph Priestley, and Benjamin Rush. [1799]

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his pamphlet on penal jurisprudence. Beccaria's principles are being attempted in U.S. University of Virginia. Tolerance of intellectual error. Upheavals in England puzzling. Queen must be a rallying point for discontented. James Maury is sending bust to T. J. [2981]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to PETER S. DU PONCEAU, Philadelphia.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp., with attached addresss leaf. Deposited by Albert H. Small. #12613-a.

scopecontent.p: TJ requests information about John Sanderson who proposed to publish a multi-volume biograhy of the Signers. TJ explains that he has already sent information on George Wythe to Sanderson and received the first volume in return and found it "superiorly written; exhibiting mind, information & polisth, a little too florid perhaps for the sober style of history ...." Believing that Sanderson might apply to him again for information on other signers TJ asks Du Ponceau about Sanderson and his purpose: "What is his character moral and political, does he write for money or fame, etc? Information as to these particulars must govern my confidences ...." TJ promises to burn Du Ponceau's reply as soon as he has received it.

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to DABNEY CARR TERRELL.
did.physdesc: LS. 4 pp. In hand of Ellen Randolph. Signed by T. J. Photostat. Original owned by Mrs. John Shelton White. #4757-b.

scopecontent.p: Ellen's copy of a letter, 1814 January 16, to Thomas Cooper of Carlisle, Pa., in which he outlined course of study for law will be enclosed. Four epochs of English Law: Bracton (Common Law), Coke, Matthew Bacon, and Blackstone. Course begins with law at time of King James, goes to Bacon, then to Blackstone and Wooddeson. Baron Geoffrey Gilbert, Cooper's edition of Justinian's Institutes (for Roman law), Reeves' History, Vaughan's Reports of Gardener and Sheldon. Mentions Browne's Compendium of the Civil and Admiralty Law, Jure Ecclesiastica, and Les Institutions du Droit et la Nature et des Gens de Rayneval, Fonblanque's edition of Francis' Treatise of Equity. [2988]

Payments to Giacomo Raggi's wife. No more money due to Michael Raggi, but he may work on columns at Carrara if Appleton wishes. Requests information on cost of capitals for the Rotunda as represented in Andrea Palladio. [1863]

did.unittitle: WILLIAM H. CRAWFORD, Washington, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: John Calhoun states that amount due to Virginia for advances during War of 1812 cannot be ascertained. Has written to Peter Hagner to speed up matter. [1864]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-5/3. Another MS. in DLC.

scopecontent.p: Recommends purchase of cement from Andrew Smith. Glass for the University. [1865]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Henrico County, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 212-214.

scopecontent.p: Cabell's illness. Requests information regarding last meeting of the Board of Visitors. Success of Samuel Blackburn, James Breckenridge, David S. Garland, Mr. Maury of Buckingham, and Joseph Shelton in the recent election. Funds for the University. [1866]

did.unittitle: JAMES MONROE, Washington, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #38-755.

scopecontent.p: Amount of claim of the Commonwealth of Virginia against the U. S. less than T. J. hoped. Claims presented by C. Selden, Virginia agent, will be paid soon. Hopes no unfavorable effect on the opening of the University. [1867]

did.unittitle: THOMAS M. HALL, Philadelphia, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Disappointed at present state of the University. Grateful for T. J.'s attention to documents placed in his care. [1868]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ALEXANDER GARRETT.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Garrett Papers, #860.

scopecontent.p: Encloses letter that may be of some help to Garrett, although T. J. has no personal relation with Governor [Lewis] Cass and no acquaintances in Detroit. [1869]

did.unittitle: JOHN HARNER, Harner's Mill, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Presenting a pair of buck's antlers. [1870]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON BOND to JAMES LYLE.
did.physdesc: DS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Bond for $2400. Receipts, dated 15 January and 15 July 1827, for $1803 from Thomas Jefferson Randolph noted on verso. [1871]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON PROMISSORY NOTE TO JAMES LYLE.
did.physdesc: DS. 1 pp. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #5533.

scopecontent.p: Witnessed by James M. Randolph and Tarleton Saunders. [2991]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON TO JAMES LEITCH.
did.physdesc: ADS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #12858.

scopecontent.p: Orders cotton cloth, lining and trimmings for two suits. "They are for servants."

did.unittitle: THOMAS COOPER, Columbia, S. C., to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Evaluation of facilities, curriculum, and faculty of South Carolina College, comparing the professor of mathematics to Nathaniel Bowditch, Audraine, and Nulty. Virginia legislature must have liberality to compete with them. Progress of Francis Eppes. Lectures in chemistry, mineralogy, criticism, Belles Lettres. [1872]

did.unittitle: JOHN F. D'OLIVEIRA FERNANDEZ, Norfolk, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Appreciates good wishes for his own and country's welfare. Recommends Dr. [Robert?] Andrews for professorship at the University. Regrets delay in opening of University, unnecessary in view of the resources of Virginia. Recommends fee system of University of Coimbra, Portugal, together with a law requiring that all pastors, lawyers, and physicians practicing in the Commonwealth be graduated from the University. Hopes Jefferson will live to see the opening of the University. [1873]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to THEODORICK BLAND.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. #698. Printed: B of R VI 38.

scopecontent.p: Opening date of University deferred until one year after the legislature remits the debt. Information on faculty, curriculum, and costs for benefit of Bland's son. [1874]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to THOMAS MANN RANDOLPH, JR., GOVERNOR OF VIRGINIA, Richmond.

scopecontent.p: Martha brought Col. Taylor's letter to Judge Roane. Hail storm damage to crops between Monticello and Mechunk, including those of Thomas Mann Randolph, Rogers, Gilmer. Trip to Bedford; work on mill. James Randolph studies Greek with T. J. and French with girls; soon to New London, Va. Funds for University and Proctor's account. Plans for Library. Literary Board. Martha not well. William and Anne Cary Randolph Bankhead at Monticello with children, except John. [2992]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JUDGE SPENCER ROANE.
did.physdesc: L. 2 pp. #38-414-a. Extract by N. P. Trist ca. 1830. Printed: L & B XV 326-329; B of R VI 393 (MS. in DLC).

scopecontent.p: Approval of John Taylor's Construction Construed. States coordinate rather than subordinate to federal government. Peculiar happiness of our system is on appeal to the ballot rather than the cannon. [1875]

did.unittitle: [BERNARD PEYTON?]. EXTENSION of LOAN.
did.physdesc: AD. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Extending the deed of trust [on Poplar Forest] to additional notes for $4000 and $2500 at the Farmer's Bank. [1876]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to THOMAS MANN RANDOLPH, JR.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. File draft. Endorsed by T. J. Another MS. in DLC. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Application for loan from the Literary Fund approved by act of the General Assembly. [1877]

did.unittitle: THOMAS MANN RANDOLPH, JR., Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #5533.

scopecontent.p: Absences from Richmond of Mr. Pendleton, Sr., and Mr. Daniel delay Literary Board. Loan directed by Legislature. Slave revolt. Wheat, flour and tobacco prices. Mentions Winchester bushel. Careers in agriculture and law. Henrico lands. Edgehill for James Randolph. Ridicule by New England is the strongest ally of education and reason in area. [2994]

did.unittitle: THOMAS MANN RANDOLPH, JR., Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Meeting of the Board of the Literary Fund. [1878]

did.unittitle: Rector and Visitors of the UNIVERSITY of VIRGINIA. BOND to the DIRECTORS of the LITERARY FUND. THOMAS JEFFERSON.

scopecontent.p: Rough draft of bond for loan of $30,000. [1879]

did.unittitle: Rector and Visitors of the UNIVERSITY of VIRGINIA. BOND to President and Directors of the LITERARY FUND.
did.physdesc: ADS by T. J. 2 pp. Seal. Witnessed by Nicholas P. Trist and William Bankhead. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Bond for a loan of $29,100. Notation: "1822. January gave a bond for 30,900. D. verbatim as this except at to the sum." [1880]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Edgewood, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 215-216.

scopecontent.p: Cabell's illness. Request for complete statement of all University accounts for the next General Assembly. Attacks on the University by the Presbyterians of Hampton-Sydney and the Episcopalians of William and Mary. Washington College to receive Robinson's estate. [1881]

did.unittitle: OWEN REYNOLDS to LOUIS H. GIRARDIN.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. RG-1/3/3.801. Endorsed by T. J.

scopecontent.p: Application for professorship of mathematics at the University of Virginia

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to [CRAVEN PEYTON].

scopecontent.p: Lame horse. Mr. Bacon's fodder accounts. Payment from Isham Randolph. Anne Bankhead and Charles Bankhead. To Bedford. Dr. Watkins to charge treatments to his sister to T. J.'s own account. [2994-a]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN BROCKENBROUGH.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. File draft. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Warrant for $14,550 to be placed to the credit of the University of Virginia at the Bank of Virginia. Mentions John Hartwell Cocke. Mentions verbatim copy addressed to Philip N. Nicholas, President of the Farmer's Bank of Virginia. [1882]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to RICHARD RUSH.
did.physdesc: L. 2 pp. Extract. 19th century copy. #1468.

scopecontent.p: T. J. asks Rush to meet with George Blaetermann and determine if Blaetermann is still interested in the position of professor of modern languages at the University of Virginia.

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON. MEMORANDUM ABOUT BOOKS FOR HIS LIBRARY.
did.physdesc: AD. 1 pp. #9753. Draft copy? Polygraph copy DLC.

scopecontent.p: Originally attached to T. J.'s letter to Richard Rush of the same date.

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON and JOHN HARTWELL COCKE, Monticello, to Joseph C. Cabell, Warminster.
did.physdesc: LS. 1 pp. #201. Endorsed by T. J. Circular. Printed: Cabell 216-217.

scopecontent.p: Proposing to defer regular autumnal meeting of the Board of Visitors until Wednesday preceding the meeting of the Assembly, when a clear and satisfactory report on construction can be given. [1883]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN HARTWELL COCKE, Bremo.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. #38-163. Endorsed by T. J.

scopecontent.p: Sends letters regarding the Board of Visitors' meeting for his signature. Trip to Bedford County. Congratulations on the change of his condition [his marriage]. Originally enclosed in [1886][1884]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JAMES E. HEATH, Auditor of Virginia.
did.physdesc: ALS.1 pp. File draft. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Encloses order from the President and Directors of the Literary Fund for $29,100 for the use of the University. [1885]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON NOTICE OF MEETING OF UNIVERSITY BOARD OF VISITORS.

scopecontent.p: To arrange affairs before General Assembly meets. Also signed by John Hartwell Cocke and James Breckenridge. [2995]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, JOHN HARTWELL COCKE to UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA BOARD OF VISITORS.

scopecontent.p: Notice of meeting.

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, JOHN HARTWELL COCKE, JAMES MADISON, CHAPMAN JOHNSON, and JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL.

scopecontent.p: Call for a special meeting of the Board of Visitors. Three identical copies, each signed by T. J. and Cocke, with one additional signature on each. [1886]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to HENRY DEARBORN.
did.physdesc: L. 1 pp. #38-414-a. Extract by N. P. Trist ca. 1830. Printed: Ford X 191-192; L & B XV 329-330; B of R VI 118 (MS. in DLC).

scopecontent.p: Missouri question has bought back the Hartford Convention men to power. Union strengthened with westward expansion. [1887]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to NATHANIEL MACON.
did.physdesc: L. 1 pp. #38-414-a. Extract by N. P. Trist ca. 1830. Printed: Ford X 192-193; B of R VI 285 (MS. in DLC).

scopecontent.p: Two necessary measures: checking invasion of states' rights by federal judiciary and paying the national debt. [1888]

did.unittitle: JOHN BROCKENBROUGH, Bank of Virginia, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Sum of $14,550 deposited to the credit of the University of Virginia. [1889]

did.unittitle: CHAPMAN JOHNSON, Staunton, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2. pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Approves special meeting of Visitors. Recommends appointment of temporary accountant as aid to Proctor. [1890]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Edgewood, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 217-218.

scopecontent.p: Meeting of the Board of Visitors. Cabell's health. Reference to Mary Cabell. [1891]

did.unittitle: JAMES BRECKENRIDGE, Fincastle County, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Approving special meeting of Visitors. [1892]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to [DANIEL BRENT, Washington, D. C.].

scopecontent.p: Order to send Brazilian ores by John Barnes. Prices of Cardelli's busts of Madison and Monroe. [1893]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN WAYLES EPPES, Mill Brook.

scopecontent.p: Course of study for Francis Eppes at Columbia College, S. C. [1894]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to SAMUEL TAYLOR, Battletown, Jefferson County.

scopecontent.p: Opening of University awaits action of Legislature on Literary Fund Loan. [2996]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JAMES MONROE, Highlands.

scopecontent.p: Lewis' letter indicates James Barron is unprincipled. [2997]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to the BOARD of VISITORS.
did.physdesc: LS. 2 pp. Circular. Enclosure: AD. 2 pp. The University of Virginia owns the copies sent to Cabell (#201) and to Cocke (#3184), and a typescript of the letter sent to Breckenridge(#251), original owned by Samuel McVitty. Printed: Cabell 219-221.

scopecontent.p: Detailed report on the cost of various buildings from information presented by Arthur Spicer Brockenbrough. Funds to be used for the library (Rotunda). Enclosure: A view of the whole expenses of the Funds of the University. [1895]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to GIACOMO RAGGI.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. File draft. Endorsed by T. J. #2737-a.

scopecontent.p: News received from Thomas Appleton of the death of Raggi's wife in Carrara, Italy. Requests orders on money being held for him. No news of Michael Raggi. [1896]

did.unittitle: GEORGE BLAETTERMANN, London, to RICHARD RUSH.
did.physdesc: L. 2 pp. Copy. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Honored by preference for professorship at the University of Virginia. Considers himself engaged. [1897]

did.unittitle: GEORGE BLAETTERMANN, London, to RICHARD RUSH.
did.physdesc: L. 2 pp. Copy. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Conveys thanks to Jefferson. Eager to teach rising citizens of a country whose government is founded on the rights of man. [1898]

did.unittitle: POPLAR FOREST ACCOUNT, E.C. METTLAR TO JOEL YANCEY.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Concerning William Mitchell's account against Jefferson. [1210]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. RG-5/3. Endorsed by T. J.

scopecontent.p: Choice of arbiters for the settlement of James Oldham's account. References to [George?] Divers and [Dabney?] Minor. [1899]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. RG-5/3. Endorsed by T. J.

scopecontent.p: Arbitration of a dispute with workers at the University by [George?] Divers and [Dabney?] Minor. [1900]

did.unittitle: ARCHIBALD THWEATT, Eppington, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Requests permission to publish T. J.'s letter on the judiciary. [1901]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Williamsburg, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 222-223.

scopecontent.p: Absence from the meeting of the Board of Visitors due to illness. Advisability of finishing all University buildings. University finances. References to Chapman Johnson and Dr. [John A.] Smith of Williamsburg. [1902]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON to ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH.
did.physdesc: DS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2737-a.

scopecontent.p: Receipt for money paid for hoisting machine for University. [1903]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to NATHANIEL MACON.
did.physdesc: L. 1 pp. #38-414-a. Extract by N. P. Trist ca. 1830. Printed: L & B XV 340-342; B of R VI 285 (MS. in DLC).

scopecontent.p: Attack on states' rights by the federal judiciary. Virginia too much out of favor to protest at this time. [1904]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to NATHANIEL MACON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Photostat. Location of original unknown. #3449.

scopecontent.p: Unauthorized publishing of his letters. Future corruption of U.S. government. Consolidating effect of judiciary. Missouri crisis. [2998]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to CLAUDIUS CROZET, West Point, New York.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Photostat. Original at ViLxV. #6924.

scopecontent.p: Treatise on Descriptive Geometry. [2999]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, UNIVERSITY RECTOR, FOR UNIVERSITY VISITORS, to SENATORS AND REPRESENTATIVES FROM VIRGINIA.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Polygraph copy. #3734.

scopecontent.p: Wants Congress to repeal import duty on books. [3000]

did.unittitle: RECTOR AND VISITORS, UNIVERSITY of VIRGINIA. PETITION to the U. S. CONGRESS.
did.physdesc: ADS. 3 pp. File draft. Endorsed by T. J. Printed: Central Gazette, 4 January 1822. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Petition to abolish tariff on scientific books imported from abroad. [1905]

did.unittitle: JOHN T. KIRKLAND, Cambridge, Mass., to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: DS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Petition from "divers Colleges, Academies, and literary and scientific Societies" to Congress to remove tariff on books. Letters from President Kirkland of Harvard College transmitting printed petition, asking signatures. [1906]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to HUGH NELSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. File draft. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Forwards copy of petition to Congress sent from Harvard College; has been asked to get signatures of institutions of South and West. Proposed it to Chapel Hill, N. C., Columbia, S. C., Athens, Ga., Transylvania, Ky. Printers do not need protective tariff. [1907]

did.unittitle: JOHN WAYLES EPPES to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Eppes' ill health. Disrespect shown Dr. Cooper by Columbia students. Requests slips of purple grape. Proposal for exchange of his land for T. J.'s Bedford lands so that Francis Eppes can settle on the Bedford estate. [1908]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JAMES BRECKENRIDGE.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #38-163-b. Printed: B of R VI 46 (MS. in DLC).

scopecontent.p: Copy of Greenlee's plat will make his patent good against a junior claim. Meeting of Board of Visitors, with John Hartwell Cocke, Chapman Johnson, and James Madison attending. State of the University published in papers. Decision on commencing the library deferred. [1909]

did.unittitle: JAMES HARRIS and ROBERT MCCULLOCK, Charlottesville, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: LS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2737-a.

scopecontent.p: Proposal for supplying lumber for central building of college. [1910]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN T. KIRKLAND, President, HARVARD COLLEGE.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. File draft. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Petition to abolish tariff on books similar to that on Kirkland's circular sent to Congress. Hopes Georgia, Kentucky, North Carolina, and South Carolina will do likewise. Happy for the occasion of cooperating with other literary institutions. [1911]

did.unittitle: SAMUEL SMITH, Washington, to T. J. Randolph.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #5533.

scopecontent.p: Unable to obtain copy of deed of conveyance from William Brust, clerk of court. Mentions Col. Morrison, Col. Nicholas and Mr. Clay. [3001]

did.unittitle: T. J. to ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH.
did.physdesc: AL. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2737-a.

scopecontent.p: Regarding the Temple of Fortuna pavilion at the University of Virginia. [1912]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON MEMORANDUM on D. MARIANO.

scopecontent.p: [Thomas] Sully's opinion of D. Mariano. [1913]

did.unittitle: MEMORANDUM ON TAXATION.

scopecontent.p: Taxes on land, slaves, horses, carriages, licenses, law processes, seals of courts, notary seals, tobacco, and military fines in all Virginia Counties. Comparison of representation and taxation of trans-Allegheny, Valley of Virginia, Piedmont, and Tidewater. [1914]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA. "HOTEL B. WEST."
did.physdesc: Paper BD. 11 3/4 x 9 in. #171.

scopecontent.p: Unfinished studies for plan and elevation. Construction completed in 1822. [N-359, K-24]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA. "HOTEL C. WEST. PROCTOR'S."

scopecontent.p: Elevation and two plans. One story. Specifications on back. Construction completed in 1822. [N-361, K-26]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA. "HOTEL D. EAST."
did.physdesc: Ink. Scale: 10' - 1". Paper BD. 10 1/4 x 12 in. #171.

scopecontent.p: Elevation and plan. One story. Specifications on back. Construction completed in 1822. [N-362, K-27]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA. "HOTEL F. EAST."
did.physdesc: Ink. Scale: 10' = 1". Paper BD. 8 1/4 x 11 1/2 in. #171.

scopecontent.p: Elevation and three plans. Two stories. Specifications on back. Construction completed in 1822. [N-363, K-28]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA. "NO. 1 PAV. WEST." SPECIFICATIONS ON BACK.
did.physdesc: Ink. Scale: 10' = 1". Paper CZ. 11 3/4 x 10 in. #171.

scopecontent.p: Construction finished 1822. [N-355, K-13]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL and CHAPMAN JOHNSON, Richmond.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. #201. Endorsed by T. J. Partly printed: Cabell 228; B of R VI 60 (MS. in DLC).

scopecontent.p: Encloses copy of letter to [Thomas] Griflin answering his letter on the subject of the University. [1915]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL. Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 5 pp. #201. Endorsed by T. J. Printed: Cabell 223-227.

scopecontent.p: Cabell in better health. Action in the Assembly regarding funds for the University. Move to shift seat of government to Staunton. Governor Randolph's differences with his Council. References to Hampden-Sydney College, Washington College, William Archer, Samuel Blackburn, Thomas Griffin, Chapman Johnson, Garrett Minor, [Richard?] Morris, Mr. Ritchie, Mr. Saunders, and Henry E. Watkins. [1916]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JAMES OLDHAM.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. RG-5/3. Endorsed by T. J.

scopecontent.p: Suggests the difficulty with Arthur Spicer Brockenbrough be settled by arbitration. [1917]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL or CHAPMAN JOHNSON, Richmond.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. #201. Endorsed by T. J. Enclosure: AD. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Printed: Cabell 228.

scopecontent.p: Enclosing a memorandum regarding funds for the University for 1822. [1918]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to THOMAS MANN RANDOLPH, JR.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. File draft. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Has executed and mailed the bond. Recommends canceling University debt and giving derelict funds for the library so that the University may open soon. Strong opposition reported by Cabell. [1919]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Partly printed: Cabell 229231.

scopecontent.p: Funds for the University. Reasons for Thomas Griffin's resolution. Opposition from the clergy. References to William and Mary, Hampden-Sydney, Chapman Johnson, Bishop [Richard Channing] Moore, Richard Morris, Rev. Mr. Rice, and Henry E. Watkins. [1920]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. #201. Endorsed by T. J. Another copy: AL. 1 pp. File draft. Deposited by Philip B. Campbell. Printed: Cabell 237.

scopecontent.p: Leaves to Cabell and his colleagues the decision as to methods of gaining relinquishment of the University debt. [1921]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 4 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Partly printed: Cabell 231-237.

scopecontent.p: Funds for the University. Advises conciliation of the clergy who are uneasy because of the predominance of the Socinians at Cambridge (Harvard), the appointment of Thomas Cooper in South Carolina, and the discovery that George Ticknor and Nathaniel Bowditch are Unitarians. References to Chapman Johnson and David Watson. [1922]

did.unittitle: DAVID HIGGINBOTHAM to THOMAS JEFFERSON.
did.physdesc: L. 1 pp. Photostat; original in Higginbotham letterbook. #3330.

scopecontent.p: Higginbotham asks T. J. to pay his debt.

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN WAYLES EPPES, Mill Brook.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Recipient's copy. #38-576.

scopecontent.p: Requesting Eppes to send House and Senate Journals, American State Papers, and certain other newspapers and public documents, 1789-1809, to be used in a project he is planning [the writing of "some notes and explanations of particular and leading transactions which history should know"; T. J. to John Wayles Eppes, 23 October 1821, DLC]. Oppressiveness of his correspondence. Reasons for refusal to exchange lands: his age; part of Bedford County lands held in trust by Bank of the United States for his endorsement for Wilson C. Nicholas; situation not inconvenient for Francis Eppes. Sends silk tree and boxwood tree for Mrs. Eppes. Will delay paying interest on his debt to Eppes. [1923]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN WAYLES EPPES, Mill Brook.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Polygraph copy. Endorsed by T. J. #38-576.

scopecontent.p: Requesting Eppes to send House and Senate Journals, American State Papers, and certain other newspapers and public documents, 1789-1809, to be used in a project he is planning [the writing of "some notes and explanations of particular and leading transactions which history should know"; T. J. to John Wayles Eppes, 23 October 1821, DLC]. Oppressiveness of his correspondence. Reasons for refusal to exchange lands: his age; part of Bedford County lands held in trust by Bank of the United States for his endorsement for Wilson C. Nicholas; situation not inconvenient for Francis Eppes. Sends silk tree and boxwood tree for Mrs. Eppes. Will delay paying interest on his debt to Eppes. [3002]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JAMES LEITCH, Charlottesville.

scopecontent.p: Order for a sifter and some rice. [1924]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 238-239.

scopecontent.p: Funds for the University. Estimate of revenue from the Literary Fund. References to John Bowyer, Chapman Johnson, and Charles Fenton Mercer. [1925]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #201. Printed: Cabell 239-240; B of R VI 60 (MS. in DLC).

scopecontent.p: Asserts that the University will have an enrollment of over 200 soon after it opens from every state south of the Ohio, Missouri, and Potomac. Urges suspension of payment of interest on the University debt. [1926]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON Monticello, to MRS. KATHERINE DUANE MORGAN.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Facsimile. #6557.

scopecontent.p: Remembers her from Washington. Mentions Col. Morgan. [3004]

did.unittitle: EDMUND BACON to THOMAS JEFFERSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #5533.

scopecontent.p: Flour from Mr. Randolph and Mr. Craven. Corn at Shadwell mill. [3003]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 240-241.

scopecontent.p: Funds for the University. The Kentucky Mission. States' Rights. References to Samuel Blackburn, Thomas Griffin, Chapman Johnson, and Richard Morris. [1927]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-5/3.

scopecontent.p: Payment of University debt. Cornices for the rooms of the western hotels. Friezes by William J. Coffee. [1928]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 242-244.

scopecontent.p: Funds for the University. The Literary Fund. References to James Breckenridge, [Charles?] Cocke, Chapman Johnson, Thomas Miller, and Richard Morris. [1929]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JAMES LEITCH, Charlottesville.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Photostat. #2753. Original owned by Mrs. J. Sharshall Grasty.

scopecontent.p: Order for linen and clothing. Mentions Burwell (slave). [1930]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to CONSTANTINE SAMUEL RAFINESQUE.

scopecontent.p: University opening delayed. To present Rafinesque's offer to teach Natural History to Board of Visitors. [3005]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 244-245.

scopecontent.p: Funds for the University. References to John Bowyer, Chapman Johnson, Richard Morris, Samuel Taylor, and David Watson. [1931]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Williamsburg, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 7 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed (in part): Cabell 245-251.

scopecontent.p: Failure to pass various bills to provide funds for the University. Reports of extravagance in construction of the buildings. Attack on the Literary Fund based on the waste of the Primary School Fund. References to Arthur Spicer Brockenbrough, Samuel Blackburn, John Bowyer, Mr. Clay, Thomas Griffin, Chapman Johnson, Richard Morris, and David Watson. [1932]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Williamsburg, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 251-254.

scopecontent.p: Meeting of the Board of Visitors. Funds for the University. Convinced that all buildings should be completed to give favorable impression. Incidental effects of the move to shift the capital from Richmond to Staunton. Attitude of the Federalist Party. References to Wilson J. Cary, George Crump, Thomas Griffin, Chapman Johnson, James Madison, and John Tyler. [1933]

did.unittitle: FRANCIS EPPES, Columbia, S. C., to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Lack of funds forces him to leave school early. Description of his studies References to John Wayles Eppes' finances. [1934]

did.unittitle: EDMUND BACON to THOMAS JEFFERSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #5533.

scopecontent.p: Paper from Mrs. Proctor and account from Mr. Vest. Mr. Stout reduced delivery. Corn and oats prices. James Monroe, through Mr. Watson, paid slaves' hire. Grain from Mr. Carr. Jerry to Milton for cement from John Crad[d]ock. Fence rail. Mentions Gill. [3006]

did.unittitle: EDMUND BACON to THOMAS JEFFERSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #5533.

scopecontent.p: James Monroe's plan to pay debt through corn sales. Mr. Rogers to sell corn. Bishop to buy timber. Isaac hauling wood. Mentions Mr. Watson and coopers. [3007]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ALEXANDER GARRETT.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2737-a.

scopecontent.p: Sends Thomas Appleton's account for marble capitals and sums to be paid Giacomo Raggi. Note by Garrett: check sent to Bernard Peyton on Farmer's Bank of Virginia. Receipt by Alexander Garrett to Arthur Brockenbrough for the money. [1935]

did.unittitle: FRANCIS EPPES, Mill Brook, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #38-755.

scopecontent.p: John Wayles Eppes can spare money only for Francis Bacon's Abridgement and Coke on Littleton. Bad crops, father's ill health make economy essential. Course of study in law. Invites Martha Randolph and T. J. to visit Mill Brook. [1936]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON ESTIMATE OF BRICKS.

scopecontent.p: Calculations for 6 shafts of Doric columns. Ordered from John M. Perry. [1937]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN ADLUM, Georgetown.

scopecontent.p: Mr. Skinner may quote T. J. letters about Adlum's wines. Caumartin grape. North Carolina's Scuppernong Creek wine and European wines. Norfolk market brandies wine too often. [3009]

did.unittitle: WILLIAM LAMBERT, Washington, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Enclosure: ADS. 7 pp. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Method of determining longitude by occultations, solar eclipses, tedious but accurate. Sends method of calculation for use of University. Enclosure: "To find the Moon's parallaxes in longitude and latitude, independent of the altitude and longitude of the nonagesimal." [1938]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON NOTES ON COSTS OF UNIVERSITY BUILDINGS.
EDMUND BACON to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #5533.

scopecontent.p: Corn prices and purchases, partly from Mr. Rogers. Horse drover from Missouri at Charlottesville to sell Chickasaw horses and a mule. T. J. note due Edmund Bacon, heir to John Bacon, with Martin Dawson. [3010-a]

did.unittitle: JOHN QUINCY ADAMS, Washington, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: DS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #38-755.

scopecontent.p: Transmits copy of public journals and documents to each state university. Noted by T. J.: State Papers of 1818, Secret Journals of Congress, Journals of Federal Convention, Census for 1820. [1939]

did.unittitle: WILLIAM LAMBERT, Washington, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges his valued note. Does not wish to burden him with astronomical labors, merely wishes to aid university in native state by supplying them accurate method for calculations of longitude. [1940]

did.unittitle: WILLIAM LAMBERT, Washington, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Enclosure: ADS. 7 pp. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Sends additional contribution to University of Virginia: "Calculations of the longitude of the Capital in the City of Washington from Greenwich Observatory, in England, from the beginning of the Solar Eclipse of August 27th 1821, Examined and revised." [1941]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN WAYLES EPPES, Mill Brook.

scopecontent.p: Regrets Eppes' illness. Disapproves of Francis Eppes' plan for early marriage but recommends acquiescence. Promises the house at Poplar Forest and a plantation with it, but since it is security for his commitment, cannot give a deed. Recommends Francis live with friends for a year before incurring expense of housekeeping. [1942]

did.unittitle: EDMUND BACON to THOMAS JEFFERSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #5533.

scopecontent.p: Carriage price. Charlottesville carriage maker not good pricing agent; Mr. Randolph better. Richmond price. T. J. Randolph says Edmund Randolph does not need Bacon at mill. Mentions Colclaser and plan to leave Virginia. [3011]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON NOTES ON SLAVES' WORK.
did.physdesc: AD. 1 pp. On verso of lettercover to [?], Monticello. McGregor Library, #3620.

scopecontent.p: Ox and mule carts of stone hauled by Wormly, Jerry, Isaac, and Ned. [3012]

did.unittitle: JAMES OLDHAM, University, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. #38-174. Endorsed by T. J.

scopecontent.p: Flooring planks arrived. Sends drawing of method of grooving floors. [1943]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to HENRY CLAY.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. File draft. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Engaging Clay's professional services in the collection of Thomas Deye Owings' bond to the late Wilson Cary Nicholas. Involvement of T. J. and Thomas J. Randolph as endorsers of Nicholas' notes. References to John Brown of Lexington, Colonel Morrison, and Dabney Terrell. [1944]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOHN QUINCY ADAMS, Washington.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. File draft. Endorsed by TJ. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: As Rector of University of Virginia, acknowledges volumes presented to it. [1945]

did.unittitle: EDMUND BACON to THOMAS JEFFERSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #5533.

scopecontent.p: Money for iron and to pay William Bacon. Bedford cart. [3013]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Edgewood, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. #2791. Endorsed by T. J. Printed: Cabell 254-255.

scopecontent.p: Illness prevents attendance at the Board of Visitors meeting. Auditing of the University's accounts by Martin Dawson. References to John Hartwell Cocke. [1946]

did.unittitle: WILLIAM LAMBERT, Washington, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Enclosure: ADS. 3 pp. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Presents table for use of University of Virginia, "A Table of Logarithms for reducing the Moon's equatorial horizontal parallax from a sphere to an oblate spheroid, admitting the ratio of the equatorial diameter to the polar axis of the Earth, to be as 320 to 319." [1947]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON REPORT as RECTOR of the UNIVERSITY of Virginia to the PRESIDENT and Directors of the LITERARY FUND.
did.physdesc: D. 1 pp. Clipping from the Charlottesville Central Gazette of 10 January 1823. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Progress of construction. Provision for religious instruction at the University. Audit of the University's books. (See entry of 23 December). [1948]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JAMES FREEMAN DANA.

scopecontent.p: Pamphlets on the disease of cattle in a certain district, and on the new invention of a water burner. Giving one to agricultural society of which James Madison is president. [3014]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH, University of Virginia.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #38-163-b.

scopecontent.p: Sends copy of resolution of Board of Visitors, authorizing building of the library, and of an advertisement for the Richmond Enquirer and Charlottesville Central Gazette regarding collection of University subscriptions in arrears. [1949]

did.unittitle: THOMAS MANN RANDOLPH (of Ashton), Norfolk, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Requests that T. J. use his influence with the President and Secretary of the Navy to help Randolph's brother-in-law, Beverly Browne, become naval storekeeper at the Gosport Navy Yard. All wine sold by Captain Crane. (This is Thomas Mann Randolph, Jr., II, younger half-brother of Thomas Mann Randolph, Jr.). [1950]

did.unittitle: DABNEY C. TERRELL, Louisville, Ky., to T. J. Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Carr-Cary Papers, #1231.

scopecontent.p: Lien on ironworks in Montgomery will shield T. J. from loss as endorser of Wilson Cary Nicholas, if Owings' bond is awarded to Thomas Jefferson Randolph. Pestilence in Louisville. Mentions Henry Clay, Mr. Green, Mr. Leigh, and William Morrison. [1951]

did.unittitle: FRANCIS EPPES, Mill Brook, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Plan for borrowing money to set up his plantation. Information from Colonel Burton about Carolina wine, made by Ebinezer Pettigrew of Edenton and George Spruel of Plymouth, sold by Thomas Cox & Co. Study of Coke. John Wayles Eppes' health. [1952]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-5/3.

scopecontent.p: University accounts with Thomas Appleton and Giacomo Raggi. Reference to Alexander Garrett. [1953]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JAMES MONROE, Washington.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. McGregor Library, #4886.

scopecontent.p: Mr. Taylor's letter. Mentions Iturbide. Hopes Brazil and Mexico will "homologize with us." Arm improved. Aid to Gibson. [3015]

did.unittitle: PETER MAVERICK, New York, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2737-a.

scopecontent.p: Forward 250 prints of the plan of the University of Virginia to Bernard Peyton, retaining plate for future orders. Includes bill. [1954]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-5/3.

scopecontent.p: Payment to Peter Maverick for his engraving of the University of Virginia ground plan. University accounts. References to Bernard Peyton. [1955]

did.unittitle: ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Statement of University accounts. Possible contracts for the library building with James Dinsmore, John Neilson, Thorn & Chamberlain, and John M. Perry. Has sent Alexander Garrett's account to Martin Dawson. [1956]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed Cabell 255-257.

scopecontent.p: Funds for the University. Literary Fund finances very unfavorable. Cabell's health improved. Glad T. J.'s wound improving. References to Wilson J. Cary, David S. Garland, William F. Gordon, Chapman Johnson, Thomas Mann Randolph, Jr., [William Cabell] Rives, and Judge St. George Tucker. [1957]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 257-259.

scopecontent.p: Cost of building the library estimated by James Dinsmore. Funds for the University. Purchase of books and apparatus. Settlement of the Proctor's accounts. References to John Bowyer, Alexander Garrett, William F. Gordon, James Hunter, George Loyall, and [William Cabell] Rives. [1958]

did.unittitle: PETER MAVERICK, New York, to THOMAS JEFFERSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-5/3.

scopecontent.p: Received payment from Col. Bernard Peyton for engraving and printing the plan of the University. [3015-a]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, RECTOR of the UNIVERSITY of VIRGINIA, to the PRESIDENT and Directors of the LITERARY FUND.
did.physdesc: D. 1 pp. Clipping from the Charlottesville Central Gazette of 10 January 1823. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Letter transmitting the report of 7 October (q.v.). Additional information on the financial status of the University. [1959]

did.unittitle: GIACOMO RAGGI, New York, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2737-a.

scopecontent.p: Awaits arrival of ships from Livorno with the University's marble capitals. Mentions Thomas Appleton. [1960]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #201. Printed: Cabell 260-262; B of R VI 60 (MS. in DLC).

scopecontent.p: Urges securing of money for the building of the library as of more importance than the remission of the University's debt. To secure a faculty of the highest order, must have distinguished structures. Estimates of the cost of the library by John M. Perry, John Gorman, James Oldham, James Dinsmore, and Arthur Spicer Brockenbrough. Extreme difficulty in writing. Mentions William Gordon, Chapman Johnson, George Loyall, and William C. Rives. [1961]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Partly printed: Cabell 263-265.

scopecontent.p: Funds for the University. Cost of the library. Error in the Proctor's accounts. References to Briscoe G. Baldwin, John Bowyer, Wilson J. Cary, John Hartwell Cocke, Peter M. Daniel, David S. Garland, William F. Gordon, Chapman Johnson, Daniel Sheffey, Allen Taylor, and Henry E. Watkins. [1962]

did.unittitle: UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA. 1923 FASCIMILE OF PETER MAVERICK'S 1822 PLAN.
did.physdesc: Design sources for pavilions written in ink by Ellen Randolph Coolidge. E332 .J48 1916

did.unittitle: EDMUND BACON to THOMAS JEFFERSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #5533.

scopecontent.p: Davy can help Joe. Estate of John Bacon. [3016]

did.unittitle: ACCOUNT BOOK KEPT AT MONTICELLO, WITH ENTRIES IN T. J.'S HAND.
did.physdesc: AD. 46 pp. Photostats. Original owned by Mrs. Robert E. Graham. #5832.

scopecontent.p: T. J. entries concern slaves. Other entries in hands of T. J. Randolph and Martha J. Randolph. [3017]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA. THE ROTUNDA.

scopecontent.p: Plan of dome room with specifications on back, beginning: "Rotunda, reduced to the proportions of the Pantheon and accomodated to the purposes of a Library for the University with rooms for drawing, music, examinations and other accessory purposes." Construction began in 1823. [N-331, K-11]

did.unittitle: WILLIAM J. COFFEE, New York, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Maverick's engraving of University ground plan. Instructions for installing ornaments for Poplar Forest and the University pavilions. T. J.'s recent fall. References to Arthur Spicer Brockenbrough, and John Hemings. [1964]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 265-266.

scopecontent.p: Funds for the University. University's popularity shown in elections in Mecklenburg, Lunenburg, Brunswick, Greenville, Henrico, Norfolk, and Essex counties. References to Mr. Clopton, James Hunter, Arthur Lee, and Addison Powell. [1965]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ARTHUR SPICER BROCKENBROUGH.
did.physdesc: ALS. 1 pp. Endorsed by T. J. RG-5/3.

scopecontent.p: Lodgings for John Gorman, a workman at the University. [1966]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #201. Printed: Cabell 266-268.

scopecontent.p: Requests that Cabell, Chapman Johnson, and George Loyall sign a special call for a Board of Visitors meeting as soon as the lower house passes the bill financing the library building. Martin Dawson's estimate of University debts higher than Arthur Spicer Brockenbrough's. Financing of a state system of education. Primary education most important, the University next, secondary schools the least. Mentions James Breckenridge, John Hartwell Cocke, and James Madison. [1967]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON RANDOLPH to THE BANK OF THE UNITED STATES, Richmond.

scopecontent.p: Concerning discharging the $20,000 debt of W. C. Nicholas.

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, T. J. RANDOLPH, and SAMUEL CARR. BOND to the PRESIDENT and MASTERS of the COLLEGE of WILLIAM and MARY.
did.physdesc: DS. 2 pp. Witnessed by Francis Eppes and D. O. Carr. Edgehill-Randolph Papers, #1397.

scopecontent.p: Loan to T. J. Randolph to discharge Wilson C. Nicholas' bond to the Bank of the United States. [1968]

did.unittitle: JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond, to THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello.
did.physdesc: ALS. 3 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #2791. Printed: Cabell 268-270.

scopecontent.p: Funds for the University and for colleges and primary schools throughout the state. Question of moving the capital from Richmond. References to Hampden-Sydney College, William F. Gordon, [William Cabell] Rives, and Samuel Taylor. [1969]

did.unittitle: THOMAS J. O'FLAHERTY, Rappahannock Academy, Caroline County, to THOMAS COOPER, President, South Carolina College.
did.physdesc: L. 4 pp. Copy [sent to T. J.?]. Greek, Latin, French, and English. RG-1/3/3.761.

scopecontent.p: Applying for a position at South Carolina College, with information on his education, experience, and devotion to the principles for which Robert Emmet died. Impossibility of returning to Ireland under present conditions. Letter of introduction from William Sampson. [1970]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to JOSEPH CARRINGTON CABELL, Richmond.
did.physdesc: ALS. 2 pp. Endorsed by T. J. #201. Printed: Cabell 270-271.

scopecontent.p: Agrees to place University first, later to come forward as patron of the primary schools. Disapproves special favors for Hampden-Sydney. Requests written approval from Board of Visitors for engaging workmen for library. Mentions Chapman Johnson, George Loyall, and William C. Rives. [1971]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ROBERT WALSH, Philadelphia.

scopecontent.p: Regrets that physical disability prevents him from providing material for Walsh's projected biography. Biography ought not to be written while the subject is alive, because of difficulty in being properly critical and because he should have access to the letters of the person while writing. ". . . the letters of a person . . . form the only full and genuine journal of his life; and few can let them go out of their own hands while they live. a life written after these hoards become opened to investigation must supercede any previous one." Correa a member of the Cortes and in poor health, disapproves of our administration. [1989]

did.unittitle: THOMAS JEFFERSON, Monticello, to ROBERT PATTERSON.
did.physdesc: ALS. 4 pp. on 1 l. #15740.

scopecontent.p: T. J. writes that he was contacted by "M. Jullien, a person of distinguished science" to be a contributor to Revue encyclopédique. The Revue's "object is, by correspondents established in every part of the world, to collect, as to a single focus, the discoveries, inventions, and advances of science generally in every country, and to present in a single mass those deemed worthy of being known." T. J. says that due to his age and "the crippled state of both my hands, writing is become too difficult and slow for me to undertake any correspondence." He hopes that by forwarding the matter to Patterson "some younger member of our society ... might be disposed to accept M. Jullien's correspondence." T. J. encloses Jullien's papers [not present] and closes by "renewing to the Philosophical Society the homage of my respect."
